Explores a cycle of gang violence that has plagued El Salvador for more than thirty years. Film follows four reformed gang members who escaped to the USA as child refugees from El Salvador's bloody civil war. They settled in the east side of LA, eventually becoming involved in street gangs. 
In an effort to suppress an epidemic of gang violence, the US began a policy of deporting undocumented gang members with felony records. When these four men return to El Salvador, they discover a country ravaged by war, and facing a new wave of violence as the LA street gangs take root in their homeland. The government, with support from the US, begin a crackdown on the gangs, and these four men find themselves in the middle of a conflict eerily similar to the civil war. As they come to terms with their two countries' violent histories, these former gang members redirect their lives towards helping young people deal with this legacy. May 2012  – Present (3 years 4 months) Santa Monica, CA After facilitating its June 2012 relaunch and vast expansion, I now oversee the multimillion-dollar category-leading Yahoo! Homes property — a content-to-commerce site formerly known as Yahoo! Real Estate — with many millions of pageviews a month. My duties include daily and big-picture tasks:  
 
+ Content strategy 
+ Simultaneous work on the existing "footprint" site as well as a groundbreaking proposed site 
+ Collaborating on the visual design and taxonomy of the proposed site 
+ Partner management as well as freelancer management (more than two dozen companies and individuals, including Forbes, CNBC, Hearst and Conde Nast publications) 
+ Lead generation 
+ Selecting, writing, editing and producing multiple stories and slideshows a day for Yahoo!’s blockbuster front page, Yahoo.com 
+ Programming Yahoo! Homes 
+ Reporting and blogging 
+ Managing social media accounts including Facebook, Twitter, Flickr, Pinterest and Instagram with our department’s social editor  
 
Among my successes: 
 
+ Over about two weeks, while handling the site solo, I helped to triple revenue from leads for one of our major partners, a leading company in the performance marketing industry. 
+ Identified and onboarded a roster of strong content partners to significantly fortify and redefine the site. 
+ I helped execute a turnaround of massively underdelivering ad impressions for a multimillion-dollar retail partnership over the course of just a week. 
+ An unusually high ratio of my blog posts appear on the Yahoo.com homepage — about half. 
+ The Yahoo! Homes Pinterest account, which was at 60 when I came aboard, is up more than 6,000%. 
+ I’m measuring labor vs. payoff in circulating traffic across the Homes site and the Yahoo! network via in-line links. Results so far: an average of roughly a million “bonus” page views each week that we wouldn’t otherwise have had. 
+ In Q1 2013, Yahoo! Homes’ group pool on Flickr doubled. Our quarterly goal had been a 50% increase. Outreach manager, Yahoo! Contributor Network Yahoo! 2011  –  July 2012  (1 year) My mandate was to find high-value writers and elevate the editorial quality of Yahoo! Contributor Network, Yahoo!’s platform and 500,000-member community for expert freelancers and user-generated content (UGC). The position, which was invented for me, straddled editorial and community functions — and I also expanded it into product solutions when appropriate:  
 
+ I recruited and cultivated dozens of notable writers including renowned travel expert Rick Steves for a $1.5 million sales project; a Hollywood screenwriter for Yahoo! Movies; a former Iowa House speaker for Yahoo! News’ caucus coverage; and two sportswriters who alone have brought millions of pageviews to Yahoo! Sports. 
+ I managed and wrote all external marketing campaigns, including banner ads, social media ads (e.g., LinkedIn and Facebook), search engine marketing (SEM), and partnerships with job sites. 
+ Through marketing, copywriting, and internal and external evangelizing, I helped rebrand YCN as Yahoo!’s entrepreneurial platform for bloggers, industry experts and thought leaders. Publishing volume from YCN to Yahoo!’s marquee sites at least doubled after my hire, as the quality of YCN content rose.  
+ I developed what was called “the most inspired editorial idea to come out of YCN” all year, a custom solution to elicit eloquent expert content from nonwriters on a mass scale. I also successfully proposed a targeting tool to filter the best assignments for the best writers. 
+ For Yahoo! sales teams, I established internal “portfolio” websites to showcase writers who could be cited in pitches and activated for sponsored campaigns such as branded microsites. 
+ I managed YCN’s presence at events including the annual conferences of BlogHer, BlogWorld, and the Online News Association (ONA).  
+ I collected, analyzed and reported data on user acquisition and activation (recruits per path of entry, conversion rate to published contributor, etc.). Editor, Yahoo! News Yahoo! January 2010  –  April 2011  (1 year 4 months) I was hired to support what became the second-biggest media launch of 2010 (according to the New York Observer). As copy editor for the blog network founded by Andrew Golis (formerly of Talking Points Media), I ensured items’ clarity and accuracy. Yahoo! News Network was No. 1 in its category, its audience about double that of runner-up CNN Network. Key achievements: 
 
+ Editors for Yahoo!’s blockbuster front page (hundreds of millions of unique users a month) requested me by name to mold and sometimes rewrite blog items destined for the Today module.  
+ On my own initiative, I analyzed headlines and click-through rates (CTR) and conducted informal A/B bucket testing to determine optimal wording.  
+ I promoted circulation throughout the Yahoo! network and quantifiably drove hundreds of thousands of page views by adding engagement links to stories, again on my own initiative during “downtime.” I measured that traffic with bit.ly links — which, anecdotally, seems to have been Yahoo!’s first use of bit.ly. After I taught co-workers about bit.ly, its use spread throughout Yahoo!. 
+ I earned a $3,000 “spot” bonus for my work as a Yahoo! News lead on the integration of Yahoo!’s $100 million acquisition Associated Content (now Yahoo! Contributor Network). I helped innovate the solicitation and use of first-person news accounts via Associated Content/YCN on Yahoo! News, and I wrote stories aggregating those reports. I won national awards for headline writing; I helped initiate the paper’s main Twitter account, @LATimes; and I was one of the first copy editors to work on the paper’s blogs. Summary Whether serving clients or creating original content, Ryan’s passion is harnessing technology to tell creative stories. Most recently, he produced & edited the award-winning feature, "The Rock ‘n’ Roll Dreams of Duncan Christopher", starring Marshall Bell. The film won the juried “Best Indie Feature” at the Edmonton International Film Festival, “Best Oklahoma Feature” at the deadCENTER Film Festival in Oklahoma City, and is being released by Gravitas Ventures in Spring 202. [iTunes: http://bit.ly/JoYw6g] 
 
In 2008, he was privileged to serve as online editor for the Oscar-nominated documentary, "The Garden", directed by Scott H. Kennedy. 
 
Born and raised in Virginia, Ryan began his Hollywood career at Avenue Pictures (Wit, Angels in America, The Player) in 2001. Since then, Ryan’s clients as an editor & graphic designer include MGM, Warner Brothers, New Line, TV Land, Mattel, Microsoft, Yahoo!, & Google. Quirky highlights include an Iggy Pop and The Bravery, to a hilarious, 2-minute national infomercial spot for Axe Boost Shower Gel. 
 
As a producer, Ryan co-founded Tandem Arts in 2004 with director Justin Monroe. Together, they produced a variety of independent films, including "Slumlord", "Burn", and "Ray of Hope". 
 
"Ray of Hope" is a series of short documentaries profiling the dramatic work of a Brazilian NGO (named Ray of Hope), as it brings education & awareness to the plight of indigenous peoples in Brazil. When the films premiered at a ROH fundraising event in 2008, contributions to the organization immediately increased 13-fold over the previous year's event. 
 
Ryan's latest passion is Breve Films, a joint venture with his writer/director wife, Gillian, which is currently in post on two films. 
 
While principally an editor, Ryan has also served as a director, director of photography, web designer, colorist, and musician. He holds a Bachelors of Science in Multi-Media, & resides in New York City.  
 
Samples of his work are at www.ryanfritzsche.com.
